prompt_evaluations.prompt: Build a simple calculator, which sould have minimum features : basic arithmetic operations (add, sub...

expected_features.prompt_description: A basic calculator with four operations
expected_features_list: basic arithmetic operations (add, subtract, multiply, divide)

features_detail.feature: basic arithmetic operations (add, subtract, multiply, divide)
features_detail.evidence: Backend handles all four operations in calculate() endpoint with proper logic for each. Frontend provides dropdown with all operations.
Frontend has two number input fields with type='number' and step='any' to accept integers and decimals. Backend accepts float operands.
Frontend has result div that updates with calculation results or error messages after API call. Test report confirms result display works.
Frontend has clear button that calls clearAll() to reset input fields and result display. Backend also has DELETE endpoints for clearing calculation history.

features_detail.feature: basic arithmetic operations (add, subtract, multiply, divide)
features_detail.evidence: Backend uses eval() to process expressions containing +, -, *, / operators. Frontend has buttons for all four operators.
Frontend has buttons for digits 0-9 and decimal point, with appendToDisplay() function to build expressions.
Input field with id='display' shows both input expression and calculated result after API call.
Clear button (C) calls clearDisplay() function that resets the display field to empty string.

pentagon.notes: Well-structured with clear separation of concerns. Uses Pydantic models for validation, proper RESTful endpoints with CRUD operations, and comprehensive error handling. Frontend has clean UI with good user feedback. Minor deduction for in-memory storage and lack of input validation beyond division by zero.

baseline.notes: Extremely minimal implementation with critical security flaw (eval() on user input). No input validation, no proper error handling, single endpoint with poor REST design. Frontend has better UI interaction but backend is dangerously insecure. Basic structure exists but lacks essential safety features.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Create a digital clock with timezone selection, which sould have minimum features : display current ...

expected_features.prompt_description: A simple digital clock with timezone support

features_detail.evidence: Backend returns hour, minute, second fields; frontend displays formatted time string with all three components.
Backend provides TIMEZONES list with 5 options; frontend populates dropdown and sends selected timezone to API.
Frontend has toggle button that switches between formats; backend processes hour_format parameter and formats time accordingly.
Frontend uses setInterval(updateTime, 1000) to poll /api/current-time endpoint every second.
Backend returns hours, minutes, seconds; frontend displays them in HH:MM:SS format and updates every second
Frontend has dropdown with 4 hardcoded timezones, backend supports any pytz timezone via API but frontend doesn't use the /timezones endpoint to show all available timezones
Toggle button switches between 12-hour (with AM/PM) and 24-hour formats, updating display accordingly
setInterval(fetchTime, 1000) calls the time API every second to update the display

pentagon.notes: Good separation of concerns with user settings management. API endpoints are well-organized. Missing proper validation for hour_format values. User settings stored in memory without persistence. Frontend incomplete (cut off).

baseline.notes: Minimalist implementation meets basic requirements. Poor API design (timezone in URL path). No user settings persistence. Limited timezone list. Frontend has hardcoded timezones. Error handling returns 200 even on errors. No input validation.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Create a todo list app with due dates and priority levels, which sould have minimum features : add t...

expected_features.prompt_description: Todo app with scheduling and prioritization

features_detail.evidence: POST /api/tasks endpoint accepts title field, frontend form includes title input with validation
Task model includes due_date field, frontend has date input, both create and update endpoints handle due_date
Priority field with validation for high/medium/low values, frontend dropdown with all three options
PATCH /api/tasks/{id}/complete endpoint, frontend toggle button with Complete/Undo functionality
DELETE /api/tasks/{id} endpoint, frontend delete button with confirmation via API call
GET /api/tasks accepts priority query parameter, frontend has priority filter dropdown
GET /api/tasks accepts sort=due_date parameter, frontend has 'Sort by Due Date' button to toggle sorting
POST endpoint /tasks accepts title parameter; frontend has input field for title and addTask() function
POST endpoint accepts due_date parameter; frontend has date input field and includes it in API call
Priority Enum defined; POST endpoint accepts priority parameter; frontend has priority dropdown
PUT endpoint /tasks/{task_id}/complete sets completed=true; frontend has Complete button that calls this endpoint
DELETE endpoint /tasks/{task_id} removes tasks; frontend has Delete button that calls this endpoint
GET /tasks accepts optional priority parameter; frontend has priority filter dropdown that calls loadTasks() with priority parameter
GET /tasks accepts sort_by_date boolean parameter; frontend has checkbox for sorting that calls loadTasks() with sort parameter

pentagon.notes: Well-structured with proper separation of concerns. Uses Pydantic models effectively, includes CORS, UUIDs, and datetime handling. Good validation and error responses. Frontend has clean separation of concerns but incomplete rendering function.

baseline.notes: Simpler but functional structure. Uses Enum for priority validation. Missing key features: no task update endpoint, no partial updates, no created_at timestamp, uses global mutable state without thread safety. Frontend uses inline event handlers and string concatenation which is less maintainable.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Build a weather dashboard that shows current conditions and 5-day forecast, which sould have minimum...

expected_features.prompt_description: Weather app with current conditions and forecast

features_detail.evidence: Backend has GET /api/cities/search endpoint, frontend has search input and searchCity() function that calls it
Backend has GET /api/weather/current endpoint returning temperature and conditions, frontend displays in currentWeather div
Weather model includes humidity and wind_speed fields, current weather endpoint returns both
Backend has GET /api/weather/forecast endpoint returning 5 days, frontend has forecast div and updateDisplay() handles it
Weather model includes icon field with emoji icons, both current and forecast endpoints return icons
Backend has PUT /api/weather/unit endpoint and unit_pref variable, frontend has toggleUnit() button and convertTemp() function, but code is truncated before full implementation
Backend has POST /api/favorites endpoint, frontend has saveFavorite() function and 'Save Current as Favorite' button
Backend has /weather/{city} endpoint, frontend has search input and searchWeather() function that calls it
Backend returns temp and conditions, frontend displayCurrent() shows temperature and conditions
Backend returns humidity and wind_speed, frontend displays both in current weather section

Backend /forecast endpoint returns 5 items, but they appear to be 5 time intervals (not necessarily 5 days). Frontend displays them as 'days' but data structure suggests it's extracting first 5 forecast periods from API
Backend returns icon code, frontend displays images from OpenWeatherMap using icon code in both current and forecast
Frontend has toggleUnits() function, units parameter passed to backend, symbol changes between °C/°F
Backend has full CRUD for favorites (GET, POST, DELETE), frontend has addFavorite(), loadFavorites(), and clickable favorites list

pentagon.notes: Better structure with Pydantic models and separation of concerns. Good naming conventions. API endpoints are logically organized. However, error handling is incomplete (favorites endpoint cut off), uses mock data instead of real API, and lacks proper data persistence.

baseline.notes: Simpler, more direct approach but less organized. Uses real weather API. RESTful endpoints but less consistent naming. Minimal error handling (only basic 404), no input validation, and global mutable state for favorites. Frontend has better error display but backend lacks robustness.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Build a personal finance tracker with expense categories, monthly budgets, and spending analytics wi...

expected_features.prompt_description: Full-featured expense tracker with budgeting and visualization

features_detail.evidence: POST /api/transactions endpoint accepts type field ('income' or 'expense'), frontend has form with type dropdown
Transaction model has category_id field, frontend category dropdown, categories can be created via POST /api/categories
Category model has budget field, PUT /api/categories/{id} updates budget, frontend has budget input for categories
GET /api/budget-progress endpoint returns spent vs budget per category, frontend displays progress section
Pie chart initialized in frontend with Chart.js but code is truncated/incomplete (missing bar chart data and pie chart updates)
Bar chart canvas exists and is initialized but code is truncated/incomplete (missing trend calculation and data aggregation by month)
GET /api/transactions accepts start_date and end_date parameters, frontend has date inputs and filter button
No export endpoint or frontend functionality found in provided code
POST endpoint /transactions/ accepts Transaction objects with type 'income' or 'expense', and frontend form allows adding both types
Transaction model includes category field, and frontend has category input field for categorization
Backend has Budget model and predefined budgets array, but no API endpoints to create/update budgets from frontend. Frontend lacks UI for setting budgets.
No API endpoint or frontend logic to compare actual spending against budget limits. Only spending aggregation exists without budget comparison.
Pie chart created using Chart.js with data from /analytics/spending_by_category endpoint
Bar chart exists but shows category spending (same as pie chart), not monthly trends over time. No aggregation by month or time-based trend analysis.
GET /transactions/ accepts start_date and end_date parameters, and frontend provides date inputs with filter button
GET /export/ endpoint returns CSV file with all transactions, and frontend has export button

pentagon.notes: Better organized with separate models for Category/Transaction. Good API endpoint naming. Missing validation for category existence in transactions. In-memory storage limits scalability. Frontend incomplete (cut off mid-function).

baseline.notes: Simpler but less organized - budgets hardcoded, no proper models for categories. Missing PUT/DELETE endpoints. No error handling for invalid data. CSV export is a plus. Frontend more complete but lacks budget management features.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Create a project management tool with tasks, team members, deadlines, progress tracking, and a kanba...

expected_features.prompt_description: Project management with kanban board and team collaboration

features_detail.evidence: POST /api/projects endpoint implemented with ProjectCreate model, creates projects with name, ID, timestamp, and progress percentage
POST /api/projects/{project_id}/tasks endpoint implemented with TaskCreate model, adds tasks with title, description, project_id, assignee, deadline, and default 'todo' status
TaskCreate model includes assignee_id field, update_task endpoint allows modifying assignee, frontend has assignee dropdown in task creation
TaskCreate model includes optional deadline field (datetime), frontend has date input for deadline, update_task endpoint allows deadline modification
Task model has status field, update_task validates status values as 'todo', 'in_progress', or 'done', Kanban board displays three columns for each status
Frontend has Kanban columns with drag-and-drop event handlers (ondrop, ondragover, drag), but backend doesn't show specific endpoint for drag updates - relies on generic task update endpoint
Project model includes progress_percentage field, GET /api/projects/{project_id}/tasks calculates progress based on done/total tasks and updates project progress
GET /api/tasks endpoint accepts assignee_id query parameter, frontend has filter dropdown that calls filterTasks() function
GET /api/tasks endpoint adds 'overdue': true flag to tasks where deadline < now and status != 'done', frontend CSS has .overdue class with red border
Backend has POST /projects/ endpoint with Project model and db_projects storage
Backend has POST /tasks/ endpoint that links tasks to projects via project_id
Backend has PUT /tasks/{task_id}/assign endpoint and Task model includes assignee field
Task model has deadline field but no API endpoint specifically for setting deadlines (only during creation)
Backend has PUT /tasks/{task_id}/status endpoint and frontend displays tasks in three status columns
Frontend has draggable tasks, drop zones, and JavaScript functions for drag-and-drop between columns
Backend has GET /projects/{project_id}/progress endpoint that calculates percentage based on done tasks
Frontend has dropdown filter that shows tasks by selected assignee in renderKanban() function
Frontend adds 'overdue' CSS class to tasks where deadline is past today and status is not done

pentagon.notes: Well-organized with clear separation of concerns. Good API endpoint design with proper HTTP methods. Missing input validation, no data persistence, and incomplete frontend implementation. CORS configured but security is lax with allow_origins: '*'.

baseline.notes: Simpler but less organized. Uses Pydantic models properly but lacks modularity. Missing many required features (no project listing, no task creation with assignee/deadline). Frontend uses mock data instead of API calls. Minimal error handling and validation.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Build an inventory management system with products, stock levels, suppliers, low-stock alerts, and s...

expected_features.prompt_description: Complete inventory management with supplier and sales tracking

features_detail.evidence: POST /api/products, PUT /api/products/{id}, DELETE /api/products/{id} endpoints exist with full CRUD operations
calculate_stock() function computes current stock from movements, GET /api/products/{product_id}/stock endpoint, current_stock displayed in frontend table
Supplier model, GET /api/suppliers and POST /api/suppliers endpoints, frontend supplier management UI
Product model has primary_supplier_id field, supplier dropdown in product form, supplier filter in product search
Product has low_stock_threshold field, check_low_stock() function, low_stock_alert flag in product responses, frontend highlights low stock rows
StockMovement model with movement_type field, POST /api/stock_movements endpoint accepts 'sale' type, frontend has stock movement form
StockMovement model with movement_type field, POST /api/stock_movements endpoint accepts 'purchase' type, supplier_id can be recorded with purchases
GET /api/inventory_valuation endpoint calculates total value based on stock × unit_price
GET /api/stock_movements endpoint with product_id filter, StockMovement model tracks all inventory changes
GET /api/products supports name search, supplier_id filter, low_stock filter, frontend has search inputs and filter dropdowns
Backend has POST, PUT, DELETE endpoints for products; frontend has add and delete functionality
Product model includes stock field, displayed in frontend table, updated during sales
Supplier model exists but no CRUD endpoints implemented; only data structure defined
Product model has supplier_id field but no functionality to set/use it in frontend or backend logic
Alerts endpoint returns products below threshold, but threshold is hardcoded (alert_threshold=10) and not configurable
/sales endpoint reduces stock and creates movement record; frontend has sales recording form
No endpoint or frontend functionality for recording purchases/stock increases
/valuation endpoint calculates total value; frontend has calculate button
Movement model exists and sales create movement records, but no endpoint to retrieve/view history
No search/filter functionality in backend endpoints or frontend interface

pentagon.notes: Better organized with separate concerns (stock calculation functions), uses Pydantic models properly, and has more complete features. However, uses in-memory dicts with manual ID management and has incomplete error handling (truncated update endpoint). Good RESTful endpoint naming with /api prefix.

baseline.notes: Minimal structure with global lists, lacks proper separation of concerns. API endpoints are basic but functional. Critical issues: stock updates directly modify product object (no audit trail), no validation on stock levels, missing many required features (supplier management, search/filter, movement history). Error handling is minimal.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Create a real-time chat application with multiple rooms, user authentication, message history, and f...

expected_features.prompt_description: Real-time chat with rooms, authentication, and file sharing

features_detail.evidence: Backend has /api/auth/register and /api/auth/login endpoints with password hashing and JWT token return. Frontend has register() and login() functions.
Backend has /api/rooms (POST/GET) and /api/rooms/{room_id}/join endpoints. Frontend has createRoom(), listRooms(), and joinRoom() functions.
WebSocket endpoint /ws/{username} handles real-time messaging with message broadcasting to all active connections.
Messages stored in memory (messages_db list) but not persisted to database. GET /api/rooms/{room_id}/messages returns history but data is volatile.
User model has status field, WebSocket updates status to online/offline, and /api/users/status endpoint returns all users' status.
Backend has /api/upload endpoint and Message model includes file_url field, but file upload is mocked (no actual storage) and file sharing not integrated into chat flow.
Message model includes created_at field, messages stored with timestamp, and frontend displays timestamp in chat messages.
WebSocket handles 'typing' message type and broadcasts to other users. Frontend has sendTyping() function and typingIndicator display.
Backend tracks unread_counts in WebSocket and frontend has unreadCount display, but no endpoint to fetch counts and UI integration is minimal.
Backend has /register and /login endpoints with user storage; frontend has UI and functions for both
Backend has POST /rooms/{room_name} and WebSocket endpoint with room joining; frontend has createRoom() and joinRoom() functions
WebSocket endpoint handles bidirectional messaging; frontend sends via ws.send() and receives via ws.onmessage
GET /history/{room} returns last 50 messages stored in memory (not persistent across restarts)
Backend tracks connected users in rooms[room]['users'] but no API to query status; frontend doesn't display status
Backend has /upload endpoint returning file_id, but no storage or retrieval; frontend uploads and sends filename only
Message model includes timestamp; backend sets datetime; frontend displays in formatted time
Frontend has typingIndicator() placeholder but no logic; backend has no support for typing events
No tracking of read/unread messages in backend or frontend; no UI element for counts

pentagon.notes: Better feature coverage with JWT auth, typing indicators, unread counts. However, uses global mutable state (users_db, rooms_db), no database, no proper session management. WebSocket logic mixes concerns, error handling incomplete (bare except). Frontend has better UI separation but incomplete functions.

baseline.notes: Cleaner, more readable code with proper WebSocketDisconnect handling. Simpler but more organized structure. Missing required features (JWT auth, typing indicators, unread counts, proper file upload). Uses Pydantic models well. Frontend is minimal but functional. Both lack production readiness (in-memory storage, no password hashing in baseline).

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Build an e-learning platform with courses, lessons, quizzes, progress tracking, and certificates, wh...

expected_features.prompt_description: E-learning platform with courses, assessments, and certification
expected_features_list: create quizzes with multiple question types
dashboard with enrolled courses and progress

features_detail.evidence: POST /api/courses endpoint creates courses, GET /api/courses lists them, Course model with instructor_id, title, description
POST /api/courses/{course_id}/lessons adds lessons to courses, Lesson model has course_id and order field for sequencing
Lesson model has content_type and content_url fields, frontend shows support for different content types

features_detail.feature: create quizzes with multiple question types
features_detail.evidence: Quiz model has questions: json field to support multiple types, but no specific question type validation or structure shown in code
POST /api/quizzes/{quiz_id}/submit endpoint compares answers with correct_answer, calculates score and pass/fail status
Enrollment model has progress_percent field, dashboard shows progress, but no automatic progress calculation from completed lessons/quizzes
PUT /api/lessons/{lesson_id}/complete endpoint sets is_completed to true, Lesson model has is_completed field
Enrollment model has certificate_url field, but no endpoint or logic shown for actually generating certificates
POST /api/courses/{course_id}/enroll endpoint, Enrollment model with learner_id and course_id

features_detail.feature: dashboard with enrolled courses and progress
features_detail.evidence: GET /api/learners/{learner_id}/dashboard endpoint returns enrolled courses with progress_percent and certificate_url
Backend has POST /courses/ endpoint with Course model, frontend has create course form
Backend has Lesson model with course_id field and GET /lessons/{course_id} endpoint
Lesson model has content_type field but no specific handling for video vs text in code

features_detail.feature: create quizzes with multiple question types
features_detail.evidence: Quiz model exists but only supports multiple-choice (options/answer), no other question types implemented
No endpoint for submitting quiz answers or auto-grading logic in the code
Enrollment model has progress field, GET /progress/{user_id}/{course_id} endpoint exists
POST /complete_lesson/ endpoint exists but only increments progress by 10%, no direct lesson completion tracking
POST /certificate/{user_id}/{course_id} endpoint checks if progress >= 100% and generates certificate
Enrollment model and POST /enroll/ endpoint implemented, frontend has enrollment form

features_detail.feature: dashboard with enrolled courses and progress
features_detail.evidence: Frontend has progress checking but no comprehensive dashboard showing all enrolled courses

pentagon.notes: Better organized with CORS, models, and consistent endpoints. Has auto-grading logic and progress tracking. However, uses in-memory dicts without proper separation, missing certificate generation, and incomplete functions. Frontend has basic UI but incomplete implementations.

baseline.notes: Simpler but functional. Has certificate endpoint and progress tracking. However, poor separation of concerns (DB as lists in global scope), inconsistent endpoints (mix of REST and RPC-style), minimal validation, and frontend is very basic with missing quiz functionality.

prompt_evaluations.prompt: Create a booking and appointment scheduling system with calendar view, availability management, remi...

expected_features.prompt_description: Appointment scheduling with calendar, availability, and customer management

features_detail.evidence: Service model with name, duration_minutes, description; POST /api/services endpoint to create services
AvailabilitySlot model with start_time, end_time, service_id; POST /api/availability endpoint to create slots with duration validation
GET /api/appointments returns all appointments but no specific calendar UI; frontend only shows booking interface, not admin calendar
Frontend HTML/JS with service selection, slot loading, customer form, and booking button; POST /api/appointments endpoint
GET /api/availability filters out booked slots; appointment creation checks for existing booked slots; update appointment validates new slot availability
Customer model exists with basic fields; appointments linked to customers via customer_id, but no dedicated endpoint to view customer history
GET /api/appointments includes reminder logic that prints to console for appointments 24-48 hours away, but no actual email sending
PUT /api/appointments/{id} accepts status and slot_id updates; frontend shows cancel button; status field handles cancellation
No endpoints or UI for filtering appointments by day/week; GET /api/appointments returns all appointments without date filtering
Appointment creation prints confirmation email to console, but no actual email system or confirmation UI beyond success message
Service class with name and duration fields, POST endpoint /services/ to create services
Slot class exists but no endpoint to create slots; slots are stored in memory but no admin interface to set them
Frontend has calendar grid showing booked/available days, loadCalendar() fetches appointments
HTML form with name, email, service, date, time fields; submits to /book/ endpoint
book_appointment checks if slot_id already exists in appointments; raises HTTP 400 if booked
Customer class exists but no endpoints to create customers; appointments store customer_id but no history tracking
send_reminders endpoint prints reminders but no actual email sending; confirmation email is simulated with print
No endpoints or frontend functionality to update or cancel appointments; only creation and listing
Calendar shows 7 days with booked status but no actual date mapping; simplified overview present
Frontend shows alert on booking success; backend prints confirmation but no actual email/SMS sent

pentagon.notes: Well-organized with clear separation of concerns. Uses Pydantic models effectively. Good API endpoint naming and structure. Includes validation for slot duration and prevents double-booking. Missing complete error handling in frontend and backend endpoints are truncated.

baseline.notes: Minimal structure with everything in single files. Basic REST endpoints but inconsistent naming (/services/ vs /book/). Very limited error handling - no validation of customer existence, service existence, or time slot logic. Frontend has hardcoded data and simplistic calendar. Missing many required features from specification.

key_findings: Pentagon Protocol significantly outperforms Baseline across most prompts
Pentagon's built-in QA achieves 100.0% test pass rate
Pentagon excels in complex prompts: 96.3% vs 87.6% features
